description.plain:
Rakim Athelaston Mayers (named after “The God MC” Rakim), better known by his stage name, A$AP Rocky, hails from Harlem, New York. He is no stranger to the cliché rap lifestyle, popularized by fellow Harlem Patriarchs, from Big L and Kool Moe Dee to Mase and Cam'ron. However, Rocky’s melodic rap style has drawn more immediate comparisons to recently incarcerated Harlemite Max B.

Rocky’s career began in 2007, when he joined the Harlem-based A$AP Mob, founded by A$AP Yams, A$AP Bari and A$AP Illz. Rocky was projected into fame in 2011 following the release of his debut mixtape LIVE.LOVE.A$AP, which featured hits like “Peso” and “Purple Swag,” and earned him a record deal with RCA Records.

His debut studio album, Long. Live. A$AP was released in 2013, after several pushbacks by his label. Long.Live.A$AP was thought to exceed the promises of his debut mixtape, preserving Rocky’s immaculate taste while smartly upgrading his sound.

After month’s of teasing projects, one of which included a completely experimental instrumental album, Rocky returned with the Juicy J aided track “Multiply” in 2014, as well as “Lord Pretty Flacko Joyde” on New Year’s 2015. Both of these tracks served as promotional singles for Flacko next record, AT.LONG.LAST.A$AP. Before the album’s release however, long-time friend and mentor A$AP Yams passed due to an overdose, which left a huge mark on Rakim ever since. The album was released on May 26th 2015, following a leak one week prior to its initial release date. Upon its release, AT.LONG.LAST.A$AP received generally positive to mixed reviews from music critics, including praises for the psychedelic anthem “L$D”.

After a brief hiatus from solo music, and an increasing indulgence into fashion and art, Rocky announced that he was working on an upcoming studio album entitled TESTING. On May 25, 2018, the album was released and was met with mixed reviews, primarily due to the album being Rocky’s most experimental project yet.

Flacko’s music can be characterised by its lucid and cloud-like feeling, though Rocky never hesitates to drop bars when he needs to. It is also thought that Rocky has some of the best music videos in the game.

However, being a staple in new-school hip-hop, Rocky’s success and accolades aren’t limited to music. He’s widely acclaimed for his impeccable fashion sense, and was named one of the most influential names in fashion of 2017. He was even featured on the cover of a 2017 issue of GQ magazine, and labeled as the “World’s Flyest Human.” He also established his own creative collective/record label AWGE in the same year.

songs.title: Fuckin’ Problems
songs.title_with_featured: Fuckin' Problems (Ft. 2 Chainz, Drake & Kendrick Lamar)

description.plain:
This all-star posse cut showcases three distinctive rappers trying to out-stunt each other on the subject of fucking “bad bitches.” Rocky called the song a “reunion” of Drake’s 2012 Club Paradise Tour, which featured Rocky, Kendrick Lamar, and 2 Chainz as opening acts.

“Fuckin’ Problems” began as a collaboration between Drake and 2 Chainz, when a line from the latter inspired the nascent song’s concept and hook. Drake and longtime producer Noah “40” Shebib, who were also working on a posthumous Aaliyah album at the time, interpolated unreleased vocal samples from the late singer to form the basis of the beat.

According to Drake, the aggressive nature of the song was a response to Kendrick and those who tried to categorize him as a “soft” artist:

It was actually Kendrick’s record first. He had asked me to get on “Poetic Justice,” and again I was like, “Oh, ‘Poetic Justice.‘” It’s a great song, but it’s the typical, you know, “I’m going to be on the soft girls song on the album.” So it was like, “Let me give you some shit.”

Drake submitted the song for inclusion on Kendrick’s good kid, m.A.A.d city album, but it was ultimately not included because it didn’t fit with the LP’s narrative.

The song finally found a home with A$AP Rocky, who released it as the second single in advance of his 2013 debut Long. Live. A$AP. According to Rocky, he was under pressure to deliver a hit. “The expectations for me [were] almost unfair, and unrealistic,” he says. “I just wanted [a song] to really back up that hype.”

Despite its explicit lyrics and title, “Fuckin’ Problems” was a major success on radio, eventually becoming a top 10 pop hit and Rocky’s most successful song to date. A video directed by Sam Lecca and Clark Jackson, and featuring all four artists, was released.

After the song became a major success, Drake reflected on his choice to give it away:


Most people would be like, “Oh, we’re going to save this for six, seven months, until my album comes out.” For me it’s, well, I’m going to give this song to someone who is popping now. We’re all on tour now. It’s a big record. It needs to come out in the next two months. I made that personal decision.

Sure, I sacrificed the record. Maybe they’ll think I’m crazy. But I’m very present in the rap game even when I’m working on an album. What I do is pick five or six songs and disperse out and say, ‘This is going to keep me very much alive in people’s minds for the next year.’

description.plain:
Featuring a slew of upcoming popular MCs over a beat crafted by Hit-Boy—the producer behind “Niggas in Paris”—"1 Train" was the most anticipated track for many prior to the release of LONG.LIVE.A$AP. Hit-Boy also produced Rocky’s first single from the album, “Goldie,” and the featured artist Kendrick Lamar can be heard on another of the album’s songs.

In an interview with Peter Rosenberg and Hot 97, Rocky explains why he chose these features, who had his favorite verse, and the significance of the track’s title.

The song hit the internet on the 18th of December 2012, the same day the entire album leaked and nearly a month prior to the actual release date.

Or ever since me and Drizzy started hangin' out, huh
Young boy, let his gun bang, let his nuts hang
Transition to a Lamborghini from a Mustang
Drugs slang in the drug game with the hustling
(I know one thing) Anything is better than that 1 Train
Bag made of Goyard, cheffin' like I'm Boyar—
Dee, probably sellin' D in your local courtyard
Braids like I'm O-Dog, my la familia go hard
Down to my inlaws, they outlaws with no laws

We outlawed then I bogart, any pros that got 'proached at

songs.full_title: Goldie by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Goldie

description.plain:
First single off of Rocky’s much-anticipated, freshman album Long.Live.A$AP.

It may be called Goldie as that was the name of the pimp in The Mack.

Fun Fact: According to Hit-Boy, this beat was originally intended for Jay Z.

Rocky told Complex:

I was in L.A. recording with Hit-Boy. We was going through some tracks. He was going through some tracks he had made for Jay-Z. He goes, ‘You ever hear this?’ He let me hear it. I go, ‘Let me get that,‘ and he let me have that record. I spit to it, and it was like, ‘This beat was made for you.’ That’s just how it worked. With ‘Goldie’ I just really wanted to show people a different side of me. I wanted to show them something jiggy. Some tastemaker shit.

The Alternate Cover Art:

songs.full_title: Praise the Lord (Da Shine) by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Skepta)
songs.title: Praise the Lord (Da Shine)

description.plain:
“Praise the Lord (Da Shine)” is the 5th track off of A$AP Rocky’s third studio album TESTING. This song marks the third collaboration between Rocky and Skepta.

The song was teased both by Rocky’s crew and Skepta on Instagram live prior to its release.

The chorus and the last two verses verse interpolate DMX’s flow on “Who We Be,” paying homage to his legendary rhyming.

Rocky released the video for the song on the 5th June, which can be viewed here. The video was shot in London and Harlem, the respective birth places of the two emcees.

The original sample is called “Andean Stroll Panpipe 02” from Apple GarageBand Jam Pack 5: World Music.

songs.title: Wild for the Night
songs.title_with_featured: Wild for the Night (Ft. Birdy Nam Nam & Skrillex)

description.plain:
Acting as Long.Live.ASAP’s third single, this track marked Rocky’s first collaboration with his friend Skrillex. In an interview with Fuse he stated that they’d “wanted to work together [for a long time] but we didn’t want to be predictable”.

The instrumental for this song is a remake of Skrillex’s remix to Birdy Nam Nam’s “Goin' In.”

The verses alternate between Rocky’s normal voice and chopped and screwed vocals—the same formula he used in “Bass,” from Live.Love.A$AP.

Behind The Scenes:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-7VQjr03MPw

songs.full_title: Peso by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Peso

description.plain:
Acting as the lead single for the mixtape Live.Love.A$AP, “Peso” was considered by many as Rocky’s breakout song. In an interview with The New York Times (who stated the track was among the year’s best) he claimed that “New York didn’t respect me until Peso”.

Big Ghost also complimented the track, saying: “This that joint that kinda gives you some idea of what Wiz Khalifa would sound like if he still had a little talent n dignity left”.

The song samples “No One’s Gonna Love You” by The S.O.S. Band:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JSEbDN49bYM#t=3

description.plain:
This song follows Rocky’s releases “Multiply” and “M'$” as the first official single for his album At.Long.Last.A$AP. Rocky stated the former two records would not appear on his new project.

This song was released to make up for the delay of  AT.LONG.LAST.A$AP, which was pushed back from May 12th to June 2nd.

On James Corden’s Carpool Karaoke series, which featured Rod Stewart as a guest, Rocky made a surprise appearance, performing the song from the backseat.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=208&v=5ndj6xn2P0c

A video for the single dropped on November 24th, 2015.
http://youtu.be/KfVIRigPyws

songs.full_title: L$D by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: L$D

description.plain:
This song and accompanying video were released on May 19 by Lil B on Twitter. Rocky later tweeted “THANK YOU BASED GOD.”

The song is both an ode to the drug LSD (commonly known as acid) and his love affairs with women. Rocky spoke on his “love for all women” during many interviews leading up to the release of this album.

Speaking to the New York Post, Rocky opened up about his latest drug of choice, LSD, citing a strong “psychedelic influence” it had on A.L.L.A..

Despite the drug-induced death of his partner and mentor A$AP Yams in January 2015, Rocky remains unapologetic for routinely indulging in drugs and women. Yams died of an accidental overdose of prescription-grade cough syrup and benzodiazepines (Xanax).

The music video was co-directed by Dexter Navy and A$AP Rocky. It also features a verse from his song “Excuse Me”. The song contains a sample of “Ode to Billy Joe” by Lou Donaldson.

The trippy atmosphere of the whole video is inspired by Enter The Void movie, directed by Gaspar Noé.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yEG2VTHS9yg

songs.full_title: Phoenix by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Phoenix

description.plain:
In this song Rocky looks deep into his career, the affects it’s having on him, and how things could’ve been much worse off. He looks at society as a whole, and at the people that compose it, and observes how we have/can destroy one another with nothing more than our words.

As annotated in the outro, the Phoenix is seen to be a symbol of rebirth, this hinting at the possibility that Rocky is trying to reinvent himself.

songs.full_title: Canal St. by A$AP Rocky (Ft. BONES)
songs.title: Canal St.

description.plain:
Canal Street is a famous crosstown street in Lower Manhattan, New York City. It’s a source for tourists to cop bootleg merchandise and is also a favorite location for arts and other cool city spots since it’s close to Chinatown, Lower East Side, TriBeca and Broadway (SoHo). When speaking to Elliot Wilson’s CRWN, Rocky claimed to have copped two of his gold chains from Canal St.



Rocky isn’t the first N.Y.C. MC to dedicate a song to Canal Street—Raekwon’s “Canal Street” was released in 2009 on Only Built 4 Cuban Linx… Pt. II.

songs.full_title: A$AP Forever by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Moby)
songs.title: A$AP Forever

description.plain:
“A$AP Forever” is the first official single released from Rocky’s upcoming album TESTING. Rocky first previewed the on Instagram live.. Flacko then premiered the song on Fallon Tonight, and dropped its video shortly after.

The track details Rocky’s loyalty to his crew, the A$AP Mob. The name possibly refers to an album of another great New York rap collective, being Wu-Tang Forever by the Wu-Tang Clan. It features a collaboration with Moby, who is a DJ known for his based electronic music. The song also samples one of Moby’s songs “Porcelain.”

The album version of this song, titled “A$AP Forever REMIX”, features guest appearances from Kid Cudi and T.I.

songs.full_title: Brand New Guy by A$AP Rocky (Ft. ScHoolboy Q)
songs.title: Brand New Guy

description.plain:
Rocky told Complex:


‘Brand New Guy’ happened before we were really cool. Like, I was a fan of Schoolboy Q before I got on. He had some song called ‘Bet I Got Some Weed,’ and ‘Druggys Wit Hoes.’ I used to listen to those songs on YouTube, watch the videos like everyday and get high to it. I really liked his music. I wanted to work with him so bad.

So by the time that ‘Purple Swag’ started buzzing just a little bit, you know Q, he’s reluctant. He doesn’t really like go collabing with artists. He’s like me. Only way he’s going to collab with you is if he really has a personal connection with you, and it should be that way, because at the end of the day, all this music and shit has to have some real kind of substance and significance to it that makes sense. If it’s just, ‘Oh, we just did this for the money,’ that doesn’t mean anything. Most people are only like that.

So when ‘Brand New Guy’ came up, it was like, I was reaching out to his people for months—not months—but a month, and it seemed like, you know, ‘Oh, he’ll do it,’ and then at that point, I was always one of those guys that wouldn’t get my hopes up high for something. I was one of those guys that would never let my hopes get up high over things like records or stuff like that.

My first day speaking, meeting, greeting Drake, he told me, ‘I’m going to bring you on tour with me.’ I didn’t believe him. It’s not that I didn’t think it would happen, I just never got my hopes up high. When I heard I was going to get a $3 million deal, I didn’t celebrate until I got a $3 million deal. It’s not up until now that I would hear something, and would kind of be looking forward to it. Like the VMAs. I heard about it. My friends didn’t even know I was doing the VMAs when I did it. That’s just how I look at things.

annotatable.link_title: Brand New Guy by A$AP Rocky (Ft. ScHoolboy Q)
annotatable.title: Brand New Guy

body.plain:
Rocky told Complex:


‘Brand New Guy’ happened before we were really cool. Like, I was a fan of Schoolboy Q before I got on. He had some song called ‘Bet I Got Some Weed,’ and ‘Druggys Wit Hoes.’ I used to listen to those songs on YouTube, watch the videos like everyday and get high to it. I really liked his music. I wanted to work with him so bad.

So by the time that ‘Purple Swag’ started buzzing just a little bit, you know Q, he’s reluctant. He doesn’t really like go collabing with artists. He’s like me. Only way he’s going to collab with you is if he really has a personal connection with you, and it should be that way, because at the end of the day, all this music and shit has to have some real kind of substance and significance to it that makes sense. If it’s just, ‘Oh, we just did this for the money,’ that doesn’t mean anything. Most people are only like that.

So when ‘Brand New Guy’ came up, it was like, I was reaching out to his people for months—not months—but a month, and it seemed like, you know, ‘Oh, he’ll do it,’ and then at that point, I was always one of those guys that wouldn’t get my hopes up high for something. I was one of those guys that would never let my hopes get up high over things like records or stuff like that.

My first day speaking, meeting, greeting Drake, he told me, ‘I’m going to bring you on tour with me.’ I didn’t believe him. It’s not that I didn’t think it would happen, I just never got my hopes up high. When I heard I was going to get a $3 million deal, I didn’t celebrate until I got a $3 million deal. It’s not up until now that I would hear something, and would kind of be looking forward to it. Like the VMAs. I heard about it. My friends didn’t even know I was doing the VMAs when I did it. That’s just how I look at things.

When I met Q, we bonded, and it became fun. We just became cool ass friends.

description.plain:
About recording the song, Rocky told Complex:

We definitely recorded that shit in some small ass closet. I was getting high. I was high as a kite. On some purple drink, purple weed, shouts to this weed. It just felt so natural. Holy shit. I was in a world where everything was purple. I was just high. Purple lights was everywhere. It was just like, dark room, purple lights. Music blasting. That type of shit. Everything is purple. Swag.

A prime example from the young Harlem spitter is this new video for his latest audible titled “Purple Swag”. It’s a song dedicated to the Houston rappers, always rapping about that purple drank (otherwise known as purple lean or codeine syrup).

This song samples:


“Stay with Me” by Clint Mansell (feat. the Kronos Quartet):
The soundtrack from Mortal Kombat 3.

songs.full_title: Babushka Boi by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Babushka Boi

description.plain:
“Babushka” is Russian for “grandmother” or “elderly woman,” and it’s also a type of Russian headscarf tied under the chin, traditionally worn by women from Eastern Europe. In November 2018, A$AP Rocky appeared at the LACMA Art+Film Gala in Los Angeles, wearing a $495 Gucci babushka.

Rocky revealed more details about the fashion choice—and the inspiration for the song—in January 2019. Apparently, the decision stemmed from a desire to hide a cut on his face, which he touches on throughout the song’s lyrics, referencing the classic 1983 gangster film Scarface. In January 2019, he told GQ magazine:

[The song] was inspired by a situation I had where my face got cut, and I started walking around with a babushka to cover it. It was about last September. It started with a yellow one when I was on Trevor Noah’s show. I actually did a Vogue shoot the day after I got my face slashed.

Rocky first previewed “Babushka Boi” during his 2019 Injured Generation tour.

songs.full_title: Angels by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Angels

description.plain:
“Angels” is a reminder of A$AP Rocky’s violent and drug-filled childhood and life before fame, as is much of LONG.LIVE.A$AP.  Through his hustle — selling marijuana and then crack cocaine at 15 — he can now stand as a small-time drug lord.  His ability to survive in dire times and come up as a prominent rapper have earned him the title as an idolized father figure for youngsters.

The track also serves as a tribute to the young kids who traffic Rocky’s drugs for him, going as far as calling them his angels.  By Rocky referring to his worker bees as angels, he may be implying that he is like a god to them.

https://twitter.com/ASVPNVST/status/282308095546384384?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw

description.plain:
This song is the first collaboration between two of hip-hop’s most fashion famous emcees.

The song samples an Indonesian song by Rasela, titled “Doa Untuk Kasih”, as well as “Much Better Off” from the legendary Smokey Robinson & The Miracles and “Who Cares” by Tony Aiken & Future 2000.

Rocky released the video for Jukebox Joints as an online MTV exclusive in August 2015.


Jukebox Joints

The second verse of the song “suddenly” speeds up, symbolizing the pace at which his career kicked off.

It samples “Suddenly” by The Cytations.

songs.full_title: Purity by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Frank Ocean)
songs.title: Purity

description.plain:
“Purity“ is the final track on A$AP Rocky’s album, TESTING, and the second track to feature Frank Ocean. “Purity“ finds an introspective Rocky looking back on his life of fame and realizing how his busy lifestyle has made it difficult for him to find time for himself and his family.

The song prominently features a pitched sample from Lauryn Hill’s MTV Unplugged No. 2.0-classic “I Gotta Find Peace of Mind“, which explains Hill’s credit on the song.

songs.full_title: A$AP Forever REMIX by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Kid Cudi, Moby & T.I.)
songs.title: A$AP Forever REMIX
songs.title_with_featured: A$AP Forever REMIX (Ft. Kid Cudi, Moby & T.I.)

description.plain:
“A$AP Forever REMIX” is the second track off of Rocky’s third studio album TESTING. The track uses a heavy bass drum kit to drive its symphony sounding instrumental.

This REMIX is a follow up to the album’s first single “A$AP Forever,” and this time, Rocky signs on T.I. and the legendary Kid Cudi to help.

The track details Rocky’s loyalty to his crew, the A$AP Mob. The track name could be a reference to an album by another great New York rap collective, Wu-Tang Forever by the Wu-Tang Clan. The song samples Moby’s “Porcelain.”

This song marks the second collaboration between Rocky and Tip, the first being T.I’s 2012 track “Wildside” from his album Trouble Man: Heavy Is the Head and the second between him and Cudi, the first being “Brothers” off of Cudi’s 2013 album Indicud.

description.plain: “Bass” is the third track from A$AP Rocky’s 2011 mixtape LIVE.LOVE.A$AP. Over a wonderful beat produced by Clams Casino, A$AP Rocky raps about money, women, and his set, deepening his voice on verses two and four to display the Texas chopped and screwed influence that looms over the mixtape and his music.

body.plain: “Bass” is the third track from A$AP Rocky’s 2011 mixtape LIVE.LOVE.A$AP. Over a wonderful beat produced by Clams Casino, A$AP Rocky raps about money, women, and his set, deepening his voice on verses two and four to display the Texas chopped and screwed influence that looms over the mixtape and his music.

songs.full_title: Sundress by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Sundress

description.plain:
“Sundress” is the first single by A$AP Rocky after the release of his third studio album, TESTING. The song and its accompanying music video were released on November 20, 2018.

The song heavily samples Tame Impala’s “Why Won’t You Make Up Your Mind?,” released on their 2010 debut album Innerspeaker. Additionally, the song features production from frequent collaborators Danger Mouse and Hector Delgado, whilst also offering Rocky’s first collaboration with Syk Sense.

“Sundress” is a highly-anticipated collaboration between Tame Impala and Rocky. News of a collaboration between the two surfaced in 2014, as a track titled “Unicorn” which sampled Tame’s “Feels Like We Only Go Backwards” leaked online, however it was never officially released by Rocky. Moreover, in September 2017, a snippet surfaced of the since unreleased song “Pretty Guy,” speculated to be produced by Kevin Parker.

The music video for “Sundress” was unexpectedly leaked on November 1, 2018, which was popularized by a since deleted Twitter post. Furthermore, Rocky performed “Sundress” live for the first time at the Camp Flog Gnaw Carnival on November 10, 2018.

songs.full_title: Holy Ghost by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Joe Fox)
songs.title: Holy Ghost

description.plain:
This song interpolates the Coen brothers movie O Brother, Where Art Thou (2000) and makes use of strong religious imagery. The Holy Ghost is a title for the third figure in the Holy Trinity described in Christianity. He is also known as the Holy Spirit. Note that the album title is a play on the word ‘Allah’, the Islamic title for God.

The central theme of the song is the corruption of institutionalized religion. Rocky refutes the necessity of such institutions, asserting that he is fine communicating with God on his own. The song has a sombre, meditative tone and closes with Rocky pleading with the Holy Ghost to help him. The rest of the album details his escapades as a famous rapper, including but not limited to problems with sex, drugs, violence, and greed — perhaps serving as a confessional for Rocky as he attempts to absolve himself of his sins.

Rocky talks about this song on his interview with Sway in the morning.

songs.full_title: Tony Tone by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Diddy)
songs.title: Tony Tone

description.plain:
“Tony Tone” is the third track off of A$AP Rocky’s third studio album TESTING. It features vocals from Puff Daddy, which also marks his first collaboration with the New York mogul.

The track revolves around how Rocky does not care about the people hating and critiquing him. In the middle of the song, there is even a small skit with a woman that gets angry at Rocky for saying explicit things.

songs.full_title: Better Things by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Better Things

description.plain:
This song explores Rocky’s relationships and issues that he has around women. Based on this interview, it’s no surprise he has girl problems.

It samples “High School Lover by Cayucas, “All Around And Away We Go” by Twin Sister, and “Carry On” by Bobby Caldwell.

In an interview with Sway, Flacko explains that this is one of the oldest songs he recorded and it was one of A$AP Yams' favorite tracks. By the time he recorded it he had problems with Rita Ora but he decided to keep it on the album because it was Yams' favorite track.

In an interview with Sway, Flacko explains that this is one of the oldest songs he recorded and it was one of A$AP Yams' favorite tracks. By the time he recorded it he had problems with Rita Ora but he decided to keep it on the album because it was Yams' favorite track.

songs.full_title: Pretty Flacko by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Pretty Flacko

description.plain:
Produced by the controversial SpaceGhostPurrp, “Pretty Flacko” is an iconic single by Harlem-based rapper A$AP Rocky released on new year’s day of 2012.

The lyrics are focused around guns, drugs, sex and money, a common theme in Rockys lyrics.

At the time of the songs release, Purrp and Rocky were very close friends, and even saw each other as brothers, but that would soon end as they started beefing later that year, resulting in them never working again.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krvzSF9qzxU

The track was later put on the collective A$AP Mob’s debut mixtape A$AP as track number 1.

To this day, it remains the most popular song SGP has ever worked on, having over 8 million views on YouTube as of 2021.

description.plain:
This track appears on the Grand Theft Auto V soundtrack on Radio Los Santos. The song was made specifically for the video game. The title would be fitting, as GTA V takes place in a fictional Los Angeles. It should be noted that featured artists, Joey Fatts and A$ton Matthews are California artists. Both artists are a part of the group, Cutthroat Boyz, along with Vince Staples.

The song title is a play on artist, R. Kelly’s name.

songs.full_title: Gunz N Butter by A$AP Rocky (Ft. Juicy J)
songs.title: Gunz N Butter

description.plain:
A$AP Rocky links up with long time collaborator Juicy J for a bass heavy track punctuated by distorted vocals, gunshots, and a brief message from DJ and producer Hector Delgado.

“Gunz N Butter” contains samples from “Cookies” produced by Dean Blunt and performed by Babyfather, “Street Type Niggaz” written and performed by Tommy Wright III and “Still Get My Dick Sucked” written by Hayward Ivy and performed by DJ Squeaky. Full production credits for each song on the album were posted on A$AP Rocky’s Twitter page the day before TESTING was released.

The title of the track refers to the guns versus butter model in economics, where government spending is broken down into two basic categories; guns (representing military spending) and butter (representing food and basic goods for citizens).

songs.full_title: Demons by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Demons

description.plain:
The fifteenth track on A$AP Rocky’s debut mixtape LIVE.LOVE.A$AP, “Demons” is an introspective look at the struggles of going through pain alone. The track is recorded over the instrumental of “Numb” by Clams Casino, the producer who helped shape the sound of Rocky’s first mixtape.

A now-deleted music video of the track was leaked onto YouTube before the song had officially been released. The video documented a day in the life of A$AP Rocky, but it turns out it was never even meant to be released. On November 29, 2011, Rocky put out a statement on his official Twitter page about the leaked clip:

songs.full_title: Houston Old Head by A$AP Rocky
songs.title: Houston Old Head

description.plain:
NYC MC A$AP Rocky pays homage to the Clutch City with “Houston Old Head”.

Despite representing Harlem, Rocky dedicates to the song to his elder role models in Houston, whom he credits as an important source of inspiration and life lessons for younger generations. In an interview with Complex, The A$AP Mob leader states that:

I’m just really influenced by Houston’s culture. That’s the shit that really gets me going…It’s melodic, so it attracted me. I’m influenced by purple drink. I don’t give a fuck. I’ll sip it, so what? I think we all should sip it. Modern-day hipster shit. When it comes to Houston, I’m really attracted to the culture. Swanging, tipping, leaning, all that. That shit is dope.”

The track is produced by DJ Burn One, who is also behind the boards on “Roll One Up” another track on LIVE.LOVE.A$AP.
